introduction.p: We say that two resistors R_1 and R_2 are connected in parallel if a current entering the combination splits and recombines immediately after going through each of the resistors as shown in . The two resistors in parallel circuit are also called two branches of the circuit and points a and b where they split or join are called junctions or nodes.

Another property to note of resistors in parallel is that the potential drops across each resistor is same for all resitors in parallel since every resistor is connected to same junction points on the two ends.

figure.caption: Two resitors connected in parallel. Current I entering the combination at junction a splits with separate currents entering the two resitors, which then immediately combine at junction b after exiting each resitor. Also, potential drop each resitor is same, viz., \Delta \phi_1 = \Delta\phi_2 = \phi_a - \phi_b.

subsection.title: Potential Drop Across Resistors in Parallel
subsection.p:
In , the resitors in parallel are connected to a voltage source such that we set up the same potential differece across both resistors.
\Delta \phi_1 = \Delta \phi_2 = \phi_a - \phi_b = V.

subsection.title: Currents in Resitors in Parallel
subsection.p:
Since a total current I comes into junction a and currents I_1 and I_2 leave and no charge accumates at a, we can apply conservation of charge to conclude the following current conservation at each junction.
I - I_1 - I_2 = 0,
that is, overall current in the circuit is
I = I_1 + I_2 = \dfrac{V}{R_1} + \dfrac{V}{R_2} = V \left(\dfrac{1}{R_1} + \dfrac{1}{R_2} \right) .
This shows that resitors in parallel divide up the total current among themselves. That is why we often refer to parallel resitors as current dividers. Solving this for V and using it in Eqs. and , we find current in each branch in terms of the total current entering or exiting the parallel resistors. After simplification we get the folloing useful formulas.
I_1 \amp = I\,\dfrac{R_2}{R_1+R_2}, I_2 \amp = I\,\dfrac{R_1}{R_1+R_2}.
Note the resistor in the numerator of each formula is the resitor in the other branch. Therefore, if other branch 2 has more resistance than branch 1, more current will flow in branch 1.

subsection.title: Equivalent Resistor of Resistors in Parallel
subsection.p:
Eq. can be written in the following way, where voltage across the parallel combination is equal to the total current and a resistor, which is called equivalent resistor of the combination, R_\text{eqiv} .
V = I\left( \dfrac{1}{R_1} + \dfrac{1}{R_2} \right)^{-1} \equiv I R_\text{equiv}.
The total current and total voltage related this way implies that the parallel combination of resistors act as if there was a single resitor of an equivalent resistance. We will also denote this equivalent resistance by R_\text{parallel} as illustrated in .
R_\text{parallel} = \left( \dfrac{1}{R_1} + \dfrac{1}{R_2} \right)^{-1} \equiv R_\text{equiv}.
This can be written in calculationally more friendly way,
R_\text{parallel} = \dfrac{R_1 R_2}{R_1 + R_2}.

figure.caption: An equvalent circuit of two resitors connected in parallel. The resitors between the common junctions a and b can be replaced by R_\text{equiv} without affecting anything outside of the resitors that have been combined if R_\text{equiv} = R_\text{parallel} = \left( \dfrac{1}{R_1} + \dfrac{1}{R_2} \right)^{-1} .

subsection.p:
We will often write Eq. as an inverse resistance, i.e., a conductance relation.
\dfrac{1}{R_\text{parallel}} = \dfrac{1}{R_1} + \dfrac{1}{R_2} \Longleftrightarrow G_\text{parallel} = G_1 + G_2,
where I have used the inverse relation between conductance G and resistance R.
G = \dfrac{1}{R}.

For N resistors in parallel, you can show that
\frac{1}{R_\text{parallel} } = \frac{1}{R_{1}} + \frac{1}{R_{2}} + \cdots + \frac{1}{R_{N}},
and the following for the conductances.
G_\text{parallel} = G_1 + G_2 + \cdots + G_N.
Hence, conductances add in a parallel circuit. Earlier, we found that resistances add up in series.

p.p: (a) Find percentage of current that passes through each resistor.
(b) Find equivalent resitance across the voltage source.
(c) Find current through the voltage source.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) In this example, current I_1 will be more than current I_2 since I_1 passes through the smaller resistance.
I_1 \amp = \left(\frac{300\Omega}{100\Omega + 300\Omega } \right) I = \frac{3}{4} I. I_2 \amp = \left(\frac{100\Omega}{100\Omega + 300\Omega } \right) I = \frac{1}{4} I.
Hence 75% of the total current passes through the 100\;\Omega resistor and 25\% through the 300\; \Omega resistor.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The equivalent resistance across the source is the equivalent resistance of parallel resitors.
R_\text{equiv} \amp = \left( \dfrac{1}{R_1} + \dfrac{1}{R_2} \right)^{-1} = \dfrac{R_1 R_2}{R_1 + R_2} \amp = \dfrac{100\Omega \times 300\Omega }{100\Omega + 300\Omega } = 75\ \Omega.

solution.title: (c)
(d)
solution.p:
(d) Using the results of (a) and (c) we get
I_1 \amp = \frac{3}{4} I = 67\text{ mA}. I_2 \amp = \frac{1}{4} I = 200\text{ mA}.

exercise.title: A Parallel Circuit of Three Resistors in Disguise

statement.p: Find current through each resistor in the circuit given in .

hint.p: Think of potential difference across each resistor.

solution.p: As before, we will choose the negative terminal of the battery as zero potential reference. Then, the positive terminal of battery is at 10 volts. We see from the diagram in that the voltage situation across each of the resistors is same: Each resistor is actually connected across the two terminals of the battery.

figure.caption: This diagram shows that one side of each resitor is connected to the negative of the voltage source while the other side is connected to the positive. That means current from voltage source will split into three branches which will then combine. Thus, the three resitors are actually in parallel, even though the diagram does not have then drawn in a traditional parallel diagram.

solution.p:
The given circuit is identical with the three resistors connected parallel to the battery. Hence the currents are
I_1 \amp = \frac{10\text{ V}} {100\ \Omega} = \frac{1}{10}\text{ A}. I_2 \amp = \frac{10\text{ V}}{200\ \Omega} = \frac{1}{20}\text{ A}. I_3 \amp = \frac{10\text{ V}}{300\ \Omega} = \frac{1}{30}\text{ A}.
